goal.preferences

Class Preferences

  • public class Preferences
extends java.lang.Object
    Author:
    V.Koeman

    • Method Detail

      • getSettingsFile

        public static java.io.File getSettingsFile()
        Returns the default settings file; possibly null when not loading/persisting from a file at all.
        Returns:
        File

      • changeSettingsFile

        public static void changeSettingsFile(java.io.File file)
        Change the default settings file. Use null to not load/persist settings from a file at all.
        Parameters:
        file - A file object (preferably a .yaml file)

      • resetToDefaultPreferences

        public static void resetToDefaultPreferences()
        Erase ALL preference changes made by the user. This recursively calls initPrefs(null) of the preferences in this package and deletes the settingsfile if present (see settingsFile field for the filepath).

        IMPORTANT: This function is also called by the GOAL Uninstaller. We do not throw here as it seems there is nothing we can do after showing the message to the user. Also not throwing is convenient for the uninstaller.

      • initializeAllPrefs

        public static void initializeAllPrefs()
        Initializes all preferences in this package. If a file exist at the path of the settingsFile field here, this (YAML) file will be used (if valid). Otherwise, an empty file will be created and default properties will be set everywhere. This needs to be called before any preferences can be used, but all preference classes do this automatically, so calling this outside of this package is not needed in normal circumstances! This function also automatically registers a Java shutdown-hook to automatically save the preferences at any termination.

      • persistAllPrefs

        public static void persistAllPrefs()
        This persists all preferences in this package to the file indicated by the settingsFile field. Notice that this is a full-save at all times (not incremental). Moreover, the initializeAllPrefs function automatically registers this function to be called at any termination, and thus this function does not need to be called manually per-se. Note that this will not throw exceptions when the file cannot be written (silent).
